title: â˜… Beeper Mini Is Back, But Without Phone Number Registration
content:
As hinted by their team over the weekend, Beeper is going to play the cat-and-mouse game with Apple. From cofounders Eric Migicovsky and Brad Murray on the Beeper blog:

Weâ€™ve created an updated version of Beeper Mini that fixes an issue that caused messages not to be sent or received.

Thatâ€™s quite the euphemistic description of the situation.

Phone number registration is not working yet. All users must now sign in with an Apple ID. Messages will be sent and received via your email address rather than phone number. Weâ€™re currently working on a fix for this.

In other words, what remains broken is the implicit creation of an iMessage account based on the cellular phone number of your device. I described this process in broad terms in a footnote on my column yesterday. Itâ€™s a magically-invisible-to-the-user process thatâ€™s been part of iMessage since it first debuted as an iOS-only feature in iOS 5.1 (At the time, â€œiOSâ€ covered iPhone, iPad, and iPod Touch.)

The â€œmagicâ€ is that you donâ€™t have to sign up for an account, or create a new username or account identifier. You just send a message from your phone number to another phone number, and if both numbers are registered for iMessage, the message goes over iMessage instead of SMS, even if you donâ€™t have an Apple ID. Beeper had that working last week. Now, Beeper users need to have an Apple ID, and sign into that Apple ID within Beeper. (Beeper should actively encourage users to create and use an app-specific Apple ID password for Beeper.)

I can confirm that todayâ€™s update to Beeper Mini in the Play Store restores the ability to use iMessage, if youâ€™re signed into an Apple ID.

Weâ€™ve made Beeper free to use. Things have been a bit chaotic, and weâ€™re not comfortable subjecting paying users to this. As soon as things stabilize (we hope they will), weâ€™ll look at turning on subscriptions again. If you want to keep supporting us, feel free to leave the subscription on ğŸ™‚.

Good on them. Like I wrote, it was irresponsible to charge a subscription fee for a service they canâ€™t guarantee access to.

Beeper Mini launched on Tuesday and rocketed to top 20 of Play Store charts. It was an instant hit. From what we can tell, Beeper Mini was the fastest growing paid Android application launch in history. In the first 48 hours, it was downloaded by more than 100,000 people.

Making it free (instead of a $2/month subscription with 7-day free trial) should only help its popularity, but I think itâ€™s an open question how much demand there is for this. iMessage users might wish their Android-owning friends would install it, but are typical Android users interested? If Android SMS users were interested in installing a third-party app to enable better cross-platform messaging, wouldnâ€™t they be suggesting to their iPhone-using friends and family that they be the ones who install WhatsApp or Signal or something?

Note: Beeper Cloudâ€™s new Oct 2023 iMessage bridge never used Mac relay servers and still does not today. It uses a similar method to Beeper Mini, but runs on a cloud server.

Beeper Cloud was relying on Mac relay servers prior to October. And I think regardless of whether the relay servers are Macs or Linux boxes, it doesnâ€™t change the fact that itâ€™s a sketchy idea to entrust a relay server with your Apple ID credentials. But I think this recent change to Beeper Cloud means that you can use an app-specific password with that, too, just like with Beeper Miniâ€‰â€”â€‰you never need to share your main Apple ID password.

Many people have asked, â€˜why donâ€™t people just use Signal or WhatsApp?â€™. The answer is that Messages App [sic] is the default chat app for all iPhone customers. Not only is it the default, iOS makes it impossible to change the default chat app. In the US, where the majority of people have iPhones, this means that the easiest way to chat is by tapping on your friendâ€™s name in your contact list and hitting the â€˜messageâ€™ button.

This is disingenuous. It is true that Apple does not allow third-party apps to handle anything related to your cellular account. So cellular phone calls only go through the built-in Phone app, and SMS messages only go through the Messages app. Messages isnâ€™t merely the default handler for SMS, itâ€™s the only handler for SMS. But there is no default for â€œchatâ€. iPhone users around the world, in countries where messaging is dominated by apps like WhatsApp or Line, have no problem ignoring Appleâ€™s Messages app. People donâ€™t start new chats in the Contacts app; they just open the messaging app they want to use. Thatâ€™s the easiest way to chat.

What theyâ€™re really arguing here is that Beeper is entitled to piggyback on the work Apple has done to make iMessage texting seamless between iOS and Mac usersâ€‰â€”â€‰and more so, that Beeper is entitled to free use of Appleâ€™s iMessage server and networking infrastructure.

We deeply object to the allegation that Beeper Mini â€˜poses significant risks to user security and privacyâ€™. This is completely untrue. As we explained above, the opposite is actually true. Beeper Mini increases the security and privacy of both Android and iPhone customers. To prove this, we published a detailed blog post about how the app keeps data secure and private. Beeper Mini is end-to-end encrypted. The underlying connection method is open source, for anyone to review.

Apple guarantees the security of both the protocol (iMessage) and the client software (Messages). In fact, because Messages only runs on Apple devices, Apple further guarantees the security of the underlying operating system and hardware that Messages (the app) runs on, and that all iMessage messages are sent between. With Beeper Mini in the mix, Apple can only guarantee the protocol and your client software, if youâ€™re using Messages. Is Beeper Mini storing cached message content and attachments securely on device? Is it transmitting privacy-sensitive metadata back to Beeper with analytics or crash logs? (Beeper Mini has a preference, â€œShare Diagnosticsâ€, that is on by default but can be disabled.) Beeper can (and does!) vouch for the privacy and security of their client app, but Apple canâ€™t. Beeper is correctly arguing that Beeper Mini does not (and cannot) compromise the security of the iMessage protocol, but that doesnâ€™t mean that its existence doesnâ€™t open security concerns for Apple and its users. And as I wrote yesterday, the existence of an unauthorized client on a supposedly closed platform creates a genuine perception problem for Apple: if Apple canâ€™t control the clients permitted to connect to iMessage, it looks like theyâ€™ve lost control of the platform. And to some degree, they have lost control over the iMessage platform.

Itâ€™s fun watching this cat-and-mouse game from the sidelines, but if I were Beeper, I wouldnâ€™t want to be playing.
